    Edge flags refactoring (#1447)
    
    * make measurement possible again #1351
    
    * refactored long flags into IntsRef
    
    * more agressive caching
    
    * made core + reader-osm modules working and tests pass
    
    * made gtfs compiling. Finally all tests are green. Yeah
    
    * removed TODO NOW, some for later some are no longer critical as all tests pass
    
    * introduce separate parsing of shared EncodedValues like roundabout to avoid duplicative work
    
    * merged master into intsref_refactoring
    
    * enable to increase edge flags to more than 8 bytes
    
    * parse bytes for edges properly
    
    * JTS downgrade to 1.15.1 #1507
    
    * introduced interfaces for EncodedValues; replaced StringEV with EnumAlikeEV; removed default for EV;
    
    * minor missing renames to EnumEncodedVAlue
    
    * fix bug with more than 4 bytes for edge flags
    
    * made cachedIntsRef cleaner and reduce object creation when there are edges and shortcuts
    
    * renamed EnumAlike to IndexBased and EnumEncodedValue to ObjectEncodedValue
    
    * use cached IntsRef for CH preparation
    
    * trying another approach
    
    * for now make setSpeed protected
    
    * Fixes some compile errors after merge, leaves some todos, only one test class is failing.

    Improvement of landmark weight precision, fixes #1080 (#1376)
    
    * Changed how the weights are stored
    
    I changed the way the landmark weights are stored from having two shorts (one for the forward and one for the backward value) to having 18 bits for the backward value and 14 bits for the difference between theese two.

    allows introducing a generic subclass that can be used to share the

commit d6f14bc7b42e647d7402f3551a03c38f50fe539d
Author: Michael Zilske <michael.zilske@gmail.com>
Date:   2018-04-07

    Dropwizardify - really now (#1314)
    
    * Initial attempt at dropwizardifying
    
    * Remove CmdArgsModule
    
    * For example: ChangeGraph
    
    * For example: Nearest
    
    * No more Guice, no more Servlets
    
    * Bundle configuration; mergin of system properties
    
    * config-example.yml
    
    * Add OSM file name to example
    
    * Add port number to example config
    
    * Dropwizard import command
    
    * ChangeGraphResource is disabled by default
    
    * rename hk2 factories to *Factory
    
    * redirect to webapp from root
    
    * dropwizard 1.1.2
    
    * Add banner.txt
    
    * Restore tests for http error status codes, and fix it.
    
    * Insert separate fields for planned/predicted departure/arrival time

commit d327bfbe8b6b18396ef05afed0efa001b302ab1a
Author: Michael Reichert <michael.reichert@geofabrik.de>
Date:   2018-01-23

    update turn info if called multiple times, fixes #1107
    
    Add a new method to TurnCostExtension which enables users to define
    their preferred merge strategy (overwrite vs. bitwise OR vs. …).
    These changes require JDK 8.
    
    replace java.util.function by a JDK7 compatible solution
    
    optimisation for simple writing of turn flags
    
    Users can circumvent the check if turn flags of a specific turn have
    already been saved.
    
    drop FlagMergeStrategy interface and replace it by simple ifs
    
    see
    https://github.com/graphhopper/graphhopper/pull/1276#issuecomment-361256037
    
    less parameters, slightly more tests but avoid bit-based tests, include clearing turn infos

59	20	core/src/main/java/com/graphhopper/storage/TurnCostExtension.java
118	0	core/src/test/java/com/graphhopper/storage/TurnCostExtensionTest.java

commit 382432d5a09f9613bee6a8a9ac5f52fd7647e499
Author: ammagamma <contactammagamma@gmail.com>
Date:   2018-02-01

    Disables checking for duplicate neigbor updates.
    
    * Previously during graph contraction a check was introduced to make
    sure each neighbor node of the current node to be contracted only gets
    updated once. However, this drastically increases CH query time, for
    example for Bremen from 3 to 40ms --> disable this check for now, but
    it would be interesting to understand why this is so!

commit 1446cf27b661caa42451d63d04ba999f0d6d6ea2
Author: ammagamma <contactammagamma@gmail.com>
Date:   2017-12-28

    Limits local witness path searches in edge-based CH.
    
    * when a certain (right now hard-coded) number of original edges have
    been settled in the witness path search, only edges are settled that might
    represent the original shortest path (current incoming edge + loops
    + current outgoing edge). this is needed because the shortest connection
    between the neighbor nodes has to be found as well and we can not simply
    stop the whole witness path search when a certain number of edges is
    settled or a certain weight is exceeded.
    
    * performance is still bad, but much better than previously:
    Bremen map: preparation time ~45s, query time ~5ms.
    
    Signed-off-by: ammagamma <contactammagamma@gmail.com>

commit 85467d016abffe3bc5e89770b935b7c459516ebb
Author: ammagamma <contactammagamma@gmail.com>
Date:   2017-12-19

    Adds edge-based node contractor and PrepareCH classes.
    
    * Adds the possibility to automatically find shortcuts and contract a
    given graph in an edge-based fashion.
    
    * This enables turn costs & restrictions in contraction hierarchies.
    
    * EdgeBasedNodeContractor and EdgeBasedPrepareContractionHierarchies
    are not yet integrated with the previous node based CH code and so far
    no automatic node ordering can be calculated, but for correctness it is
    most important that the query results are correct for ANY contraction order.
    For automatic node contraction ordering EdgeBasedNodeContractor needs
    to return the required metrics (to calculate edge difference / quotient etc.).
    
    * This commit only focuses on correctness and adds extensive tests,
    there are many border cases with parallel shortcuts, loops etc. that
    have to be accounted for.
    
    * No support for U-Turn traversal mode (not sure if it even makes sense)
    
    * Shortcut edges are used in fwd direction only, so the memory consumption
    is potentially (almost) doubled (assuming that most shortcuts can be travelled
    in both directions), but using fwd&bwd flags requires some changes because
    then it is harder to decide what the 'first' and 'last' original edges are.
    
    * There are some very obvious potential performance improvements that
    are left to be done, some are mentioned as todos. So far the contraction
    has not been tested on a bigger graph.
    
    Signed-off-by: ammagamma <contactammagamma@gmail.com>

295	0	core/src/main/java/com/graphhopper/routing/ch/EdgeBasedNodeContractor.java

commit 2409d0dbad1e5f9ea88e89c65672d997a89c937f
Author: Andi <contactammagamma@gmail.com>
Date:   2017-12-18

    Extracts new class NodeContractor from PrepareContractionHierarchies. (#1225)
    
    * Does some minor clean-up in PrepareContractionHierarchies.
    
    * some simple restructuring to prepare NodeContractor extraction
    * some readability improvements
    
    * Reorders fields and methods in PrepareContractionHierarchies.
    
    * reordering is supposed to make diffs easier to read when NodeContractor is extracted
    * besides the reordering no code is changed
    
    * Decouples some code in PrepareContractionHierarchies.
    
    * because findShortcuts shall be attributed to NodeContractor in the future
    it needs to be decoupled from meanDegree (meanDegree is used by PrepareContractionHierarchies
    to determine the node ordering). to achieve this another variable
    maxVisitedNodes is introduced.
    * the changes made to findShortcuts are replaced by corresponding code
    that is inserted before / after the few places where findShortcuts is
    called, if this is needed
    
    * Extracts the methods that will belong to NodeContractor in PrepareContractionHierarchies
    
    * creates the methods (getters etc. that will belong to NodeContractor)
    
    * Creates inner static class NodeContractor in PrepareContractionHierarchies.
    
    * NodeContractor is responsible for searching for witness paths and adding required
    shortcut edges for a given node that shall be contracted
    
    * PrepareContractionHierarchies is responsible for determining the order
    in which nodes are contracted and provides the interface to start the
    contraction of a graph
    
    * Makes NodeContractor a proper class.
    
    * adjusts some access modifiers so NodeContractor can be moved out of PrepareContractionHierarchies
    
    * adds some documentation
    
    * otherwise does not change the code
    
    * Renames getNewShorcuts in NodeContractor.
    
    * some minor clean-up
    
    * Disallows non-node-based graph traversal for CH.
    
    * makes NodeContractor (and thereby PrepareContractionHierarchies) throw an exception
    when it is called with edge-based traversal mode, because it is not
    supported yet
    
    * Tries to clarify the role of meanDegree in PrepareContractionHierarchies.
    
    * meanDegree / tmpDegreeCounter variables are a bit confusing as they do not
    represent the degree of a node (number of adjacent edges)
    
    * Fixes error message in NodeContractor#setOrigEdgeCount
    
    * fixes todo in NodeContractor#setOrigEdgeCount, the previous implementation returned
    the number of original edges where most likely the number of original edges + shortcuts
    was meant.
    
    * Fixes setting of maxVisitedNodes for witness path searches in PrepareContractionHierarchies.
    
    * so far maxVisitedNodes was always set to zero in prepareNodes() / calculatePriority()
    because meanDegree was initialized only afterwards in contractNodes()
    this means so far the priorities were not calculated right because no witness
    paths could be found.
    
    * this fix requires adjusting three tests that depend on the contraction
    order. adjusted createExampleGraph instead of testAddShortcut, because
    testAddShortcut does no longer find a shortcut with the example graph.
    the other tests using createExampleGraph are not be affected by this change.
    
    * Fixes cast of meanDegree to maxVisitedNodes in PrepareContractionHierarchies.
    
    * previously maxVisitedNodes was 0 if meanDegree < 1.
    * this change affects the node contraction order and one test had
    to be adjusted.
    
    * Cleans-up NodeContractor and PrepareContractionHierarchies.
    
    *  postpones creation of NodeContractor in PrepareContractionHierarchies to
    initFromGraph(), gets rid of NodeContractor#setMaxEdgesCount
    
    * makes levelFilter in PCH a local variable
    
    * Adds NodeContractorTest
    
    * moves testShortcutMergeBug to NodeContractorTest
    * removes PCH#testAddShortcuts
    
    * Moves some tests from PrepareContractionHierarchiesTest to NodeContractorTest and cleans up.
    
    * these tests basically 'misuse' PCH only to set the node priorities to the
    maximum level
    
    * makes PCH#initFromGraph,prepareNodes,contractNodes private
    
    * removes PCH#testFindShortcuts
    
    * some clean-up
    
    * Adds comment in NodeContractor#initFromGraph
    
    * Adds more tests to NodeContractorTest, sets default maxVisitedNodes from 0 to max.
    
    * so far NodeContractor used a default maxVisitedNodes of 0, which did
    not make much sense
    
    * Adds a todo about obscure behavior of AllCHEdgesIterator in NodeContractorTest.
    
    * for some reason AllCHEdgesIterator returns a shortcut where both
    skipped1/2edges are 0
    
    * Adds to NodeContractorTest.
    
    * adds another test, adds some infrastructure now that AllCHEdgeIterator
    is fixed.
    
    Signed-off-by: ammagamma <contactammagamma@gmail.com>
    
    * Fixes (some) climate code issues.

    * Fixes more climate code issues.

    * Removes NodeContractor#testFindShortcuts, cleans up NodeContractorTest.

    * Reverts fixes of the node contraction order.

commit e601eb8db2d53e3287be262e0722fb4bc60fdd68
Author: Andi <contactammagamma@gmail.com>
Date:   2017-10-23

    Implements a simple version of stall-on-demand for CH queries. (#1179)
    
    * Implements a simple version of stall-on-demand for CH queries.
    
    * Makes stall on demand the default for CH. Moves different CH routing algorithms to routing package.
    
    * Renames CH algorithms.
    
    * Adds measurements for CH without stall on demand.
    
    * minor cleanup
    
    * Adds tests revealing bug in stall on demand implementation.
    
    Stall on demand can prevent finding a shortest path if the weight of an
    edge depends on the driving direction as with Motorcycle or Bike2 weightings.
    
    * Fixes bug in stall on demand implementation.
    
    When checking the stall on demand condition so far the wrong edge
    direction was used to calculate the weight of the incoming edge.
    
    * Adjusts prevOrNextEdge parameter in stall on demand check.
    
    * Adds author tag and removes stall on demand public constant.
    
    * Adds author tag and removes stall on demand public constant.
    
    * Fixes compile error.

commit 11efb7ae6289a66b7a34644b2b40e12bb49de40f
Author: Robin <boldtrn@users.noreply.github.com>
Date:   2017-08-17

    Add Average Speed as PathDetails to Response (#1091)
    
    * First proposal to add path details
    * Use number of points to determine the interval for pathdetails
    * Improved JS debugging code
    * Changed the way PathDetails are stored to a list instead of a Map
    * Store pathdetails with number of points, not intervals
    * Store pathdetails in a map and let jackson handle the serialization
    * Updated according to review comments
    * Fixed Via Point Issue
    * Added PathSimplification for Instructions and PathDetails

commit 2247498835808daac94ef9f1ad07638e0887bd9d
Author: Robin <boldtrn@users.noreply.github.com>
Date:   2017-05-02

    SpatialRuleLookup Refactoring (#987)
    
    * Updated SpatialRuleLookup initialization
    * Allowed defining the names of the SpatialRules
    
    * Improved number of spatial rules definition
    
    * Woops, fixed the tests :)
    
    * Moved Reflections into the Web Module
    
    * Updated Example Config
    
    * The SpatialRuleLookupArray is now told its bounds at creation, and that's enough. No need to have getBounds() on the interface.
    No need to allow null as a SpatialRuleLookup. A SpatialRuleLookup which never returns a rule is much better.
    
    * Remove setting the number of spatial rules from properties.
    
    * Remove possibility of SpatialRuleLookup to be null anywhere. One which always returns EMPTY_RULE should be fine.
    
    * The cut for the landmark preparation has not a lot to do with SpatialRules -- it just needs an EdgeFilter.
    
    * Ich gehe davon aus, dass SpatialIndex und SpatialRule interfaces sind, die DataFlagEncoder gehören, und erstmal gegeben sind.
    Ich habe die buildIndex-Methode aus DefaultModule rausgenommen und in eine eigene Klasse geschrieben. Weil hier ein Länderindex erzeugt wird, habe ich sie einfach Countries genannt und in ein eigenes Package gepackt.
    Untewegs habe ich noch eine Unterklasse einer Factory entfernt. Da warst Du quasi zu bescheiden: Die Oberklasse konnte schon alles, was hier passiert. Man konnte sie einfach benutzen (mit entsprechenden Parametern), anstatt von ihr zu erben.
    Die Art erster Wahl, Funktionen zu kombinieren, sollte immer das "zurückführen auf" sein, also das benutzen einer vorhandenen Klasse mit entsprechendem Input. Dann kommt das Kombinieren aus mehreren bestehenden Klassen. Benutzen sein. Dann kommt ganz, ganz lange gar nichts, und dann kommt irgendwann vielleicht Vererbung. "Favor composition over inheritance".
    Für kleine Klassen, die eigentlich gar nichts machen (wie Factories), ist Vererbung ein viel zu dickes Fass. Vererbung sollte es nur geben, wo man sich am Anfang hingesetzt hat und beschlossen hat, dass Vererbung die richtige Lösung für genau dieses Problem ist und alle beteiligten Klassen extra für Vererbung gebaut sind.
    
    * Deine Implementierung des SpatialRuleLookup interfaces in sein eigenes Package geschoben. Kann im Core sein, muss aber nicht.
    Dafür habe ich den Konstruktor public gemacht, was kein Problem ist, weil in diesem Fall der Konstruktor kein Geheimnis ist bzw. sein kann: Die Implementierung braucht nunmal
    die BBox vorher, um zu funktionieren. Das darf man ruhig sehen, wenn das so ist.
    
    * Der DataFlagEncoderTest soll sehen, ob der DataFlagEncoder richtig mit seinem SpatialRuleLookup umgeht. Gibt zwei Möglichkeiten: Entweder, er erzeugt selber eine Quatsch-Implementierung von SpatialRuleLookup. Das hat den Vorteil, dass man gleichzeitig sieht, wie einfach oder schwer SpatialRuleLookup eigentlich zu implementieren ist. Idealerweise sollte es einfach sein, denn es ist wirklich nur ein Lookup, wie der Name schon sagt. Wenn man dafür sehr viele Methoden implementieren muss, ist das ein Zeichen, dass irgendetwas hier zu viele bewegliche Teile hat.
    Gleichzeitig hatte ich das Gefühl, dass Du hier diesen Builder deswegen benutzt, weil die Erzeugung von Deinem SpatialRuleLookupArray so kompliziert ist, weil die BoundingBox berechnet werden muss. Nun kann man sagen, wenn die BoundingBox eh vorher feststehen muss, sind wahrscheinlich auch schon die SpatialRules vorher da (woher wüsste man sonst die BoundingBox), deswegen kann man die auch gleich im Konstruktor übergeben, erklärt SpatialRuleLookupArray für immutable -- und schwupps, muss man nichts mehr über BoundingBoxes wissen (weil er sie selbst ausrechnen kann), und man braucht den Builder nicht mehr.
    Deswegen kann ich ihn jetzt in com.graphhopper.countries verschieben. Siehe Fortsetzung.
    Unterwegs habe ich einen Test entfernt, der anscheinend getestet hat, dass der Index ungenauer ist, als er sein muss. Wenn er seine BoundingBox selbst ausrechnet, anstatt eine geschätzte übergeben zu bekommen, ist er anscheinend genauer.
    
    * Jetzt zum Builder. Der Builder ist eigentlich nur ein halber Builder: Er hat (was gut ist) gar keinen inneren Zustand. Seine Methoden wollen eigentlich statisch sein.
    
    * Damit fällt der Builder, der eigentlich keiner ist, mit der Countries-Klasse zusammen. Das trifft sich gut, denn wir waren uns ja eh nicht so ganz sicher, ob die Trennung zwischen der Polygon-Seite und der Regel-Reflection-Seite unbedingt genau so sein muss, wie sie ist. Also erstmal flachklopfen.
    
    * Weiter flachklopfen. Jetzt wird alles in einer einzigen Methode aufgebaut, die zwar ziemlich lang ist -- aber das ist eine Abwägung gegen die Anzahl der beweglichen Teile, und die war vorher sehr hoch -- lauter Interfaces, Factories, Builder, Objekte und Vererbung. Wenn es nur darum geht, eine Methode zu unterteilen, sind einfach weitere (private) Methoden "Refactor --> extract method" Mittel der Wahl.
    Jetzt sehen wir auch die beiden for-Schleifen untereinander.
    
    * Ich hab die beiden for-Schleifen mal umgestellt: Erst mache ich eine Map aus den Features, dann erzeuge ich die Rules. Das hat den charmanten Vorteil, dass es die Rules nur in einem Zustand gibt, nämlich in fertig -- und nicht einmal in fertig und einmal in unfertig, wobei sie in beiden durch die Gegend gereicht werden.
    Das ist jetzt ein bisschen Geschmackssache, aber meiner Meinung nach braucht man nicht zu versuchen, auf jeder Ebene maximal defensiv gegen alle Arten von Datenfehlern zu sein. Durch das Wegfallen von Ebenen können bestimmte Fehler gar nicht mehr auftreten -- wenn ich ein Objekt gerade selber erzeugt habe, brauche ich nicht mehr zu checken, ob es null ist (das sagt mir dann auch die IDE). Aber ich würde sogar behaupten, dass das hier ein Importer für *eine* Datei ist, nämlich für die, die da im Resource-Pfad liegt. Ziel ist es, den einfach genug zu klopfen, dass ein User ihn als Beispiel nehmen kann, wie sein eigener Importer für seine eigene Datei aussehen kann.
    Und wie diese *eine* Datei aussieht, wissen wir, sie ist ja eingecheckt. Deswegen brauchen wir nicht gegen Datenfehler zu hedgen, von denen wir wissen, dass diese Datei sie nicht hat. Bzw. können auch ein bisschen darauf vertrauen, dass es dann eben eine NullPointerException gibt, wenn das id-Feld nicht gesetzt ist oder dergleichen.
    (Auch, weil viel "haarigere" Tests ja gar nicht gemacht werden: Überlappen sich die Polygone? Du schreibst (was völlig OK ist), dass der Lookup selber entscheiden kann, wie er damit umgeht. Dann, finde ich aber, ist es auch OK, wenn ein bisschen unspezifiziert ist, was z.B. passiert, wenn eine id doppelt ist.
    
    * Wenn wir jetzt *nicht* mehr Reflection machen, *dann* wird die Factory auf einmal wieder interessant. Dann ist nämlich die *Factory* das, was man austauscht, und die selber weiß, was es für SpatialRules es gibt, und die man *selber* ggf. per Reflection austauschbar machen könnte, wenn's sein muss, *statt* der einzelnen Rules. Die kann dadurch dann auch viel mehr: Nämlich selber entscheiden, ob evtl. mehrere Länder die gleiche Regel haben sollen, oder ob sie selber einfach ad-hoc-Implementierungen des Interfaces erzeugt, etc.
    
    * Jetzt hab ich die andere Verwendung des SpatialRuleLookup von Peter wieder aktiviert und auch wieder zu Deinem alten Namen umbenannt. Solche Klassen, die nur statische Methoden (oder nur eine) haben, heißen oft *Util, oder auch nur der Plural des Interfaces (so wie Collections), man könnte sie vielleicht einfach SpatialRules nennen, oder SpatialRulesLookupUtil
    
    * Jetzt kann die add-Methode vom SpatialRuleLookup weg -- gibt keinen Grund, das zu unterstützen. SpatialRuleLookup ist nur zum lesen da, wie der Name schon sagt.
    
    * Jetzt können, aus dem gleichen Grund, die Setter von SpatialRule weg.
    Vermutlich könnten sogar auch noch getId() und getBorders() aus SpatialRule weg (das wäre noch ein bisschen Aufwand, aber eigentlich werden die da gar nicht gebraucht - die Polygone und die Id werden nur durch die Factory durch im Kreis herum gereicht, denn als "Transportobjekt" von der serialisierten Form bis in den Index brauchen wir die jetzt eigentlich nicht mehr. Der FlagEncoder interessiert sich nur für die Werte selbst, nicht für die Identität oder die Geometrie.
    Aber irgendwann ist auch mal Schluss. :-)
    Eine Frage hab ich noch: Wie soll das Interface von SpatialRule wachsen? Immer, wenn der DataFlagEncoder sich für ein neues Attribut interessiert? Wäre es auch denkbar, das Interface umzudrehen, so dass es die Schnittstelle SpatialRule.apply(DataFlagEncoder dfe, ...) hat, und der kann dann den DataFlagEncoder benutzen und da was reinschreiben, statt umgekehrt? Dann müsste vielleicht nur _ein_ Interface erweitert werden (DataFlagEncoder) statt zwei, wenn man Attribute hinzufügen will.
    
    * Jetzt war mir nur noch ein Test um die Ohren geflogen, weil der Encoder für die spatialId manchmal null war. So wie ich das sehe, ist das gar nicht nötig, dass er das ist.
    Es gibt insgesamt in GraphHopper sehr viele Arten, auf die etwas an oder aus sein kann: Irgendwas ist null, etwas ist "disabled", etwas hat Anzahl 0, und Kombinationen davon.
    - Ein SpatialRuleLookup, der immer EMPTY zurückgibt, ist besser als einer, der null sein kann (worauf man dann immer extern testen muss)
    - Ein ValueEncoder, der eine Range von 0 bis 0 hat und damit 0 bit breit ist, ist besser als einer, der null sein kann (worauf man dann immer extern testen muss)
    ... etc.
    Das reduziert den Zustandsraum, in dem die Software sein kann, erheblich. :-) Ausserdem weiss man automatisch, dass die Randfälle funktionieren, weil sie sich quasi von alleine
    aussortieren, wenn man alles richtig gemacht hat: Über eine leere Liste iterieren und damit irgendwas machen hat (wenn alles stimmt) den gleichen Effekt, wie wenn ich noch extra if(list.empty) return null einbaue.
    
    * Remove FQN
    
    * Removed SpatialRuleLookupEnabled method
    
    * Removed Unused BBox method
    
    * Reverted LandmarkStorage change
    
    * Removed import
    
    * Moved the Rules/SRLArr back to the core
    
    * Allowed defining the BBox of the SpatialRuleLookup
    
    * Reverted getId
    
    * Removed TestRule from DataFlagEncoder
    
    * Changed default resolution .1, I think this makes more sense than using 1.0
    
    * Fixing minor todos
    
    * Fixed Tests
    
    * Improved formatting of config-example
    
    * Updated config description
    
    * Added documentation

commit c486feac0d3955f635efc22ddb43f91e47df8824
Author: Michael Zilske <michael.zilske@gmail.com>
Date:   2017-03-10

    MMapDataAccess should synchronize on its ByteBuffers by itself (#982)
    
    MMapDataAccess is now thread-safe. MMapDataAccess now synchronizes on its ByteBuffers by itself, and is now as thread-safe as the other implementations.
    Remove the dimension of "synched" or "not synched" from DataAccess.
    Remove tests which tested this dimension.

commit e085c0b3f3b1e8a3b5942d0938218bec40a357f3
Author: Peter <graphhopper@gmx.de>
Date:   2017-02-22

    ALT algorithm for a more dynamic speed up (#780)
    
    * new feature: speed up routing via landmark preparation #780
    * make visited nodes for ALT algo visible
    * use proper subnetwork detection algorithm. Simple via Dijkstra and strict two-direction filter does not work properly
    * make distance dependent on maximum bounds
    * use spatial lookup for landmarks
    * make distance guess fixed and bigger
    * print warning if too many entries were maxed out
    * added landmarks to all integration tests, include edge based and turn cost, using ConnectionNotFoundException
    * added some documentation for landmarks, moved more prepare.xy parameters, fixed tests
    * enable landmark algorithm for alternative_route
    * define astarbi as default to avoid too many friction to get started with landmarks
    * make it possible to specify manual landmarks per subnetwork; added dynamic recalculation but this does not work yet without manual tuning
    * major improvement for response time of automatic landmark finding via using weight==1 instead distance; split area only for LM preparation and add unit test; fix factor calculation for small areas; make it possible to load split area geojson from file

commit dfc54e6c2062632121a327671754158dcf3416da
Author: ammagamma <contactammagamma@gmail.com>
Date:   2016-08-24

    Makes it possible to use imperial units (miles&feet) in GH web
    
    - Adds new url parameter use_miles(=true/false) and two buttons in the instructions
      window to choose the unit system.
    - Stores the chosen unit system as a flag inside GHRequest (but not in
      GHRequest.api_params as it is not used by the GH api, similar to the do_zoom
      parameter).
    - Adds some test for the unit conversions.
    - Updates leaflet.elevation version to (so far unreleased version) 0.0.4 which
      features the option to show the elevation data in feet instead of meters.
    - Slightly increases the left margin of the elevation plugin window to make the
      y-axis label visible. For some reason the label is placed further to the left
      than in earlier versions of leaflet.elevation.
    - Copies the white-theme style class used earlier for the elevation window to
      the new leaflet.elevation css file.

commit 9778a23b3dbaffdb930ef995363b89169c554c37
Merge: 7559f6e28 e0ec282c8
Author: Peter <graphhopper@gmx.de>
Date:   2016-01-26

    Merge pull request #648 from fbonzon/patch-1
    
    Wrap coordinates around dateline

commit e0ec282c818d436cf8ec6af913f77f72fe03aa44
Author: François B <fbonzon@users.noreply.github.com>
Date:   2016-01-26

    Wrap coordinates around dateline
    
    When browsing another copy of the world, left or right the central main one, after right-clicking on the map to add start, end, or intermediate points, error is displayed:
    Cannot find point 0: 52.50452,373.351135
    Cannot find point 1: 52.516639,373.428383
    
    This PR will make all clicks with longitude -180 to +180 degrees.
    
    Uses the [wrap()](http://leafletjs.com/reference.html#latlng-wrap) function from Leaflet.
    
    It's not a complete solution to this issue, as the route is always drawn on the main copy of the world. However, the error is gone, and and the map is automatically panned to the route anyway (in main copy of world).

3	3	web/src/main/webapp/js/main-template.js

commit 649c185c3dbec24d2daf809a827aed1b9333dfb9
Merge: 1053ab2cc 34bacf6b3
Author: Peter <graphhopper@gmx.de>
Date:   2015-12-21

    Merge pull request #615 from fbonzon/patch-1
    
    web UI: Change default precision from 1 m to 10 m for distance label

commit 34bacf6b351013b94ac4e79c48329327b752f7cc
Author: François B <github@bonzon.com>
Date:   2015-12-20

    Change default precision from 1 m to 10 m for distance label on elevation profile
    
    Unless you are looking at directions for a very short distance, say total distance about < 1 km (which is not common), moving the mouse on the elevation profile by just 1 pixel will never make only the 3rd decimal digit change. 2nd decimal digit changes too. Thus 3rd digit is not significant and can be removed.
    
    I'm hesitating about 2nd digit. It could be removed too in most cases. With directions about > 10 km long, the 2 digit is not significant when mousing over the elevation profile.
    
    Other minor changes:
    
    ForceAxisBounds = false is default anyway
    Keeping "yAxisMin: 0" alone is useless unless "forceAxisBounds = true"
    
    Add missing exports
    
    Remove trailing space

10	10	web/src/main/webapp/css/style.css

commit 846f549612505c89c6ba67996f69d226b193d81b
Author: ratrun <ratrun@gmx.at>
Date:   2015-08-23

    Elevation control didn't show up
    
    The elevation control in the web GUI does not show up. 8009563b0f7638459006fe6c306dcb579ad5203c was the reason. In `GHRequest.prototype.init = function (params)` parameter  `this.vehicle` was still used, although the assignment was removed. So this should be changed into 'params.vehicle'.
    
    The same is true below in 'GHRequest.prototype.initVehicle = function (vehicle) {` where 'this.vehicle' needs to be replaced with 'vehicle'.

2	2	web/src/main/webapp/js/ghrequest.js

    Adopation of testNorthBayreuthFootFastestAnd3D:
    
    This is the current solution:
    
    https://graphhopper.com/maps/?point=49.986111%2C11.550407&point=50.023182%2C11.555386&vehicle=foot&layer=Omniscale
    
    With the modification we get routed on this longer solution, which is OK because there it contains a longer segment on the relation rwn "Markgrafenweg Bayreuth-Kulmbach", see
    
    https://graphhopper.com/maps/?point=49.986111%2C11.550407&point=50.002554%2C11.538666&point=50.023182%2C11.555386&vehicle=foot&elevation=true&layer=WanderReitKarte

commit 3f77dbed10fcfa9c2c5fd27ffcdc9a46646d9e3a
Author: ratrun <ratrun@gmx.at>
Date:   2015-07-29

    Fix testMonacoEnforcedDirection: In the test testMonacoEnforcedDirection the better solution is longer now. It is correct because the direction instructs to go south at the start. The previous solution went north at the start. I have tested this with this URL
    
    http://localhost:8989/?point=43.741069%2C7.426854&point=43.744445%2C7.429483&heading_penalty=300&heading=190&vehicle=foot&layer=Omniscale
    
    Unfortunately the actual Monaco OSM data has very different highway tags compared to the checked in Monaco OSM data snapshot, so the backgound tiles are a bit confusing.

Author: svantulden <sander.vantulden@falk.nl>
Date:   2015-04-21

    Added nearest API
    
    - Call /nearest?point=lat,lon to get the nearest point on the prepared
    graph
    - Returns point and distance to point when succesful
    - Returns error if no input is given or if a nearest point cannot be
    found (due to index resolution)

    Tuning for bicycles classifications for the sac_scale tag:

commit 63f95ba93c441ca2d3bab917ae1b628150c18c53
Author: JohannesPelzer <johannes.pelzer@gmx.de>
Date:   2014-04-22

    1. removed calcOrientationNorth, remove the '@Deprecated' from calcOrientation, and changed
    
    depending functions
    2. reduced precision of GPX double values (lat,lon,distance) and also of distance in json response
    to configurable values. Default is 6 digits on right side of comma/point
    
    3. intentionally blank
    
    4. suggestion div should now be hiding when zoom buttons are clicked or markers are dragged.
    marker dragging does not change focus, so the specific drag handler was changed
    Additionally "cursor: pointer" is used for suggestion divs

commit fab257514eab5c26ce6f6ba2a4dd733ebd1cd110
Author: ratrun <ratrun@gmx.at>
Date:   2014-01-03

    Make all tests pass now. The change about the used bits relation code in changeset 4332356 was wrong. The bug that the configured vehicles influenced the result of each others was caused by using the WayBitMask instead of the RelBitMask in handleWayTags of the EncodingManager.
    Additionally the SafeWayBit is commented now, as it is nowhere used.
    -->With this version it is now possible to configure the combiantion of e.g. BIKE,MTB,RACINGBIKE.

commit 4332356373b317ae0d58e7d22730dd3700261398
Author: ratrun <ratrun@gmx.at>
Date:   2014-01-03

    During the creation of testMonacoMountainBike, testMonacoRacingBike() and extension of testKremsBikeRelation() I detected a bug in the usage of the RelationCode bits: The bits used were not added to the bits for the ways. This resulted in different routes, depending on the list of the configured vehicle types. Now this bug is fixed, but as a side effect it is not possible to activate three encoderes in parallel, because then we would exceed the used bits.

commit 7b7c7f9630fc24d5f7fb190083068748f9dfcd6e
Author: Karl Hübner <karl.huebner@tolina.de>
Date:   2013-12-27

    Import of turn restrictions (OSM).
    
    OSM relations of type "restriction" will be imported. According to the
    restriction type, several entries will be added to a turn cost table.
    Furthermore, the turn flag encoder is now implemented by the current
    edge encoders (e.g., foot flag encoder do not store any turn flags).
    Import can be enabled by GraphHopper#setEnableTurnRestrictions(true),
    which is disabled by default.

commit 7f85ee7a0d1aa6190cc2d688f885a6a65d506392
Merge: 2007a9c15 df78b0474
Author: Peter <peathal@yahoo.de>
Date:   2013-12-22

    Merge pull request #134 from khuebner/master
    
    Preparing support of turn restrictions (2): Encode turn costs depending on vehicle type

commit df78b047411bc3b895a66694de879a46962a414e
Author: Karl Hübner <karl.huebner@tolina.de>
Date:   2013-12-22

    Next to FlagEncoders for edge properties, TurnCostEncoders are now held
    by the EncodingManager. A TurnCostEncoder encodes and decodes turn
    restrictions/turn costs of several vehicle types into an integer flag,
    like FlagEncoders do. For CAR, BIKE a DefaultTurnCostEncoder has been
    declared, which stores turn restrictions only (yet). For FOOT a
    NoTurnRestrictionEncoder has been defined, which encodes whether
    restrictions nor costs. To define which TurnCostEncoders should be used,
    the EncodingManager accepts a second list of turnCostEncoders, which can
    be defined the same way as edgeFlagEncoders are defined.
    
    However, those TurnCostEncoders are not beeing used anywhere in the
    code. This is just preparation for turn restriction support, which will
    be introduces step by step.

68	0	core/src/main/java/com/graphhopper/routing/util/AbstractTurnCostEncoder.java
42	0	core/src/main/java/com/graphhopper/routing/util/DefaultTurnCostEncoder.java
116	40	core/src/main/java/com/graphhopper/routing/util/EncodingManager.java
63	0	core/src/main/java/com/graphhopper/routing/util/TurnCostEncoder.java
135	0	core/src/test/java/com/graphhopper/routing/util/DefaultTurnCostEncoderTest.java
4	4	core/src/test/java/com/graphhopper/routing/util/EncodingManagerTest.java

commit 2007a9c15d62fb14edaec49aaa87d806fadcb002
Merge: 512752a9f 2fe6b05bf
Author: Peter <peathal@yahoo.de>
Date:   2013-12-22

    Merge pull request #133 from khuebner/master
    
    Preparing support of turn restrictions: Extended GraphStorage

commit 2fe6b05bf2b6488fb75225141584053a6dc21c35
Author: Karl Hübner <karl.huebner@tolina.de>
Date:   2013-12-22

    Added the possibility to set one additional value for both edges and
    nodes. By default no additional values will be stored and current graphs
    are still valid. Any implementation of ExtendedStorage can be put into
    GraphHopperStorage, which take care of any additional storages, which
    depends on nodes or edges ( e.g. turn cost tables) by reading/writing
    those additional values. An example implementation can be found in
    TurnCostStorage.
    
    This will be mandandatory to implement support of turn restrictions
    later.
